editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The nightwalker, or the little thief.
A comedy, as it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke: 1640.

div.head: To the worthily-deserving all his ingenuous attributes William Hudson esq.
div.p: I should derogate from your worth, to doubt of your pardon, and if should wrong too much your goodness to present the endeavours of some frothy brain to the trial of your judgement, when the more ignorant world had already condemned it; but sir, this is one of the coheirs of much admired, much lamented Fletcher, whose matchless fancies are fit only for the perusal of such as you, who have candour and knowledge so united, that there cannot be a reprieve for those poems you condemn; accept this weak testimony of my service, and as yours by familiar acquaintance with them, favourably entertain these witty conceits particularly presented unto you, by him who shall glory in nothing more than to be styled

div.head: The nightwalker: or, the little thief.

sp.stage: Enter Tom Lurcher and Jack Wildbrain.

sp.speaker: Lurc.
sp.l: Jack.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What wind brought thee hither?
In what old hollow tree, or rotten wall
Hast thou been like a swallow all this winter,
Where hast thou been man?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Following the blow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What blow? Thou hast no land,
Stealing's thy own purchase.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The best inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not in my opinion,
Thou hadst five hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis gone,
Prithee no more on't, have I not told thee,
And oftentimes, nature made all men equal,
Her distribution to each child alike;
Till labour came and thrust a new will in,
Which I allow not: till men won a privilege
By that they call endeavour, which indeed
is nothing but a lawful cozenage,
An allowed way to cheat, why should my neighbour
That hath no more soul than his horsekeeper,
Nor bounteous faculties above a broom man,
Have forty thousand pound, and I four groats;
Why should he keep it?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Thy old opinion still.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why should that scrivener
That never writ reason in his life, nor any thing
That time e'er gloried in, that never knew
How to keep any courtesy concealed
But noverint universt must proclaim it,
Purchase perpetually, and I a rascal:
Consider this, why should that mouldy cobbler
Marry his daughter to a wealthy merchant,
And give five thousand pound, is this good justice?
Because he has a tougher constitution;
Can feed upon old songs, and save his money,
Therefore must I go beg?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What's this to thee?
Thou canst not mend it, if thou beest determined
To rob all like a tyrant, yet take heed
A keener justice do not overtake thee,
And catch you in a noose.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am no woodcock,
He that shall sit down frighted with that foolery
Is not worth pity, let me alone to shuffle;
Thou art for wenching.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: For beauty I, a safe course,
No halter hangs in my way, I defy it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But a worse fate, a wilful poverty,
For where thou 'gainst by one that indeed loves thee,
A thousand will draw from thee, 'tis thy destiny;
One is a kind of weeping cross Jack,
A gentle purgatory, do not fling at all,
You'll pay the box so often, till thou perish.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Take you no care for that sir, 'tis my pleasure,
I will employ my wits a great deal faster
than you shall do your fingers, and my loves,
If I mistake not, shall prove riper harvest
And handsomer, and come within less danger.
Where's thy young sister?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I know not where she is, she is not worth caring for,
She has no wit.
O you'd be nibbling with her,
She's far enough I hope, I know not where,
She's not worth caring for, a sullen thing
She would not take my counsel Jack,
And so I parted from her.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Leave her to her wants?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I gave her a little money what I could spare,
She had a mind tooth country, she is turned
By this some farrier's dairy maid, I may meet her
Riding from market one day twixt her dorsers;
If I do, by this hand I wonot spare
Her butter pence.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Thou wilt not rob thy sister.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: She shall account me for her eggs and cheeses.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A pretty girl, did not old Algripe love her,
A very pretty girl she was.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Some such thing,
But he was too wise to fasten; let her pass.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Then where's thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Where you sha'not find her,
Nor know what stuff she is made on, no indeed sir,
I chose her not for your use.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Sure she is handsome.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes indeed is she, she is very handsome, but that's all one

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You'll come tooth marriage.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Is it today.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Now, now, they are come from church now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Any great preparation,
Does justice Algripe show his power.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Very glorious, and glorious people there.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I may meet with him yet ere I die as cunning as he is.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You may do good Tom at the marriage,
we have plate and dainty things.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Do you no harm sir,
For yet methinks the marriage should be marred
If thou mayst have thy will, farewell, say nothing.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You are welcome noble friends.
I thank you sir,
Nephew to the old lady, his name is Wildbrain,
And willed his best condition.
I have heard of him,
I pray ye tell me sir, is young Maria merry
After her marriage rites? does she look lively?
How does she like her man?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Very scurvily,
And as untowardly she prepares herself,
But 'tis mine aunt's will, that this dull mettle
Must be mixed with her to allay her handsomeness.
Had Hartlove no fast friends?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: His means are little,
And where those littles are, as little comforts
Ever keep company: I know she loves him,
His memory beyond the hopes of —
Beyond the Indies in his mouldy cabinets,
But 'tis her unhandsome fate.
I am sorry fort,
Here comes poor Frank, nay we are friends, start not sir,
We see your willow and are sorry for,
And though it be a wedding we are half mourners.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good gentlemen remember not my fortunes.
They are not to be helped with words.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Look up man,
A proper sensible fellow and shrink for a wench,
Are there no more? or is she all the handsomeness?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Prithee leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prithee leave thou whining,
Have maids forgotten to love?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You are injurious.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Let 'em alone a while, they'll follow thee.
Come good Frank,
forget now, since there is no remedy,
And show a merry face, as wise men would do.
Be a free guest, and think not of those passages.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Think how to nick him home, thou knowest she dotes on thee;
Graft me a dainty meddler on his crabstock;
Pay me the dreaming puppy.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Well, make your mirth, the whilst I bear my misery;
Honest minds would ha' better thoughts.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am her kinsman,
And love her well, am tender of her youth,
Yet honest Frank, before I would have that stinkard,
That walking rotten tomb, enjoy her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Prithee leave mocking.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prithee Frank believe me,
Go to consider, hark, they knock to dinner,
Come wilt thou go?
I prithee Frank go with us,
And laugh and dance as we do.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You are light gentlemen,
Nothing to weigh your hearts, pray give me leave,
I'll come and see, and take my leave.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: We'll look for you,
Do not despair, I have a trick yet.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes,
When I am mischievous I will believe your projects:
She is gone, for ever gone, I cannot help it,
My hopes and all my happiness gone with her.
Gone like a pleasing dream: what mirth and jollity
Reigns round about this house? how every office
Sweets with new joys, can she be merry too?
Is all this pleasure set by her appointment?
Sure she has a false heart then; still they grow louder
The old man's god, his gold, has won upon her
(Light hearted cordial gold) and all my services
That offered naked truth, are clean forgotten:
Yet if she were compelled, but it cannot be,
If I could but imagine her will mine,
Although he had her body.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He shall come in.
Walk without doors of this day, though an enemy,
It must not be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You must compel him madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No she shall fetch him in, nephew it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It will be fittest.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Can fair Maria look again upon me?
Can there be so much impudence in sweetness?
Or has she got a strong heart to defy me?
She comes herself: how rich she is in jewels!
Methinks they show like frozen icicles,
Cold winter had hung on her, how the roses
That kept continual spring within her cheeks
Are withered with the old man's dull embraces?
She would speak to me. I can sigh too lady
But from a sounder heart: yes, and can weep too
But 'tis for you, that ever I believed you,
Tears of more pious value then your marriage;
You would encase yourself, and I must credit you,
So much my old obedience compels from me;
Go, and forget me, and my poverty,
I need not bid you, you're too perfect that way:
But still remember that I loved Maria,
Loved with a loyal love, nay turn not from me,
I will not ask a treare more, you are bountiful,
Go and rejoice, and I will wait upon you
That little of my life left.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good sir hear me,
What has been done, was the act of my obedience
And not my will: forced from me by my parents,
Now 'tis done, do as I do, bear it handsomely
And if there can be more society
Without dishonour to my tie of marriage
Or place for noble love, I shall love you still,
You had the first, the last, had my will prospered;
You talk of little time of life: dear Frank,
Certain I am not married for eternity,
The joy my marriage brings tells me I am mortal
and shorter lived than you, else I were miserable;
Nor can the gold and ease his age hath brought me
Add what I coveted, content, go with me,
They seek a day of joy, prithee let's show it
Though it be forced, and by this kiss believe me
However , I must live at his command now,
I'll die at yours.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have enough, I'll honour ye.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here are my trinkets, and this lusty marriage
I mean to visit, I have shift of all sorts,
And here are thousand wheels to set 'em working,
I am very merry, for I know this wedding
Will yield me lusty pillage, if mad wild-goose
That deboshed rogue keep but his ancient revels
And breed a hubbub in the house I am happy.
Now what are you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A poor distressed boy sir,
Friendless and comfortless, that would entreat
Some charity and kindness from your worship,
I would fain serve sir, and as fain endeavour
With duteous labour to deserve the love
Of that good gentleman shall entertain me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A pretty boy, but of too mild a breeding,
Too tender and too bashful a behaviour,
What canst thou do?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I can learn any thing
That's good and honest, and shall please master.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He blushes as he speaks, and that I like not,
I love a bold and secure confidence,
An impudence that one may trust, this boy now
Had I instructed him had been a jewel,
A treasure for my use, thou canst not lie.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I would not willingly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor thou hast no wit
To dissemble neatly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do you love such boys, sir?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O mainly, mainly, I would have my boy impudent,
Outface all truth, yet do it piously:
Like Proteus, cast himself into all forms,
As sudden and as nimble as his thoughts,
Blench at no danger, though it be the gallows,
Nor make no conscience of a cozenage
Though it be ith' church; your soft, demure, still children —
Are good for nothing, but to get long graces —
And sing songs to dull tunes; I would keep thee
And cherish thee, hadst thou any active quality,
And be a tender master to thy knavery,
But thou art not for my use.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do you speak this seriously?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Would you have your boy sir
Read in these moral mischiefs?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Now thou movest me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And be a well trained youth in all activities?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Or do you this to try me,
Fearing a proneness.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I speak this to make thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then take me sir, and cherish me and love me;
You have me what you would: believe me sir
I can do any thing for your advantage,
I guess at what you mean; I can lie naturally,
As easily, as I can sleep sir, and securely:
As naturally I can steal too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That I am glad on,
Right heartily glad on, hold thee there, thou art excellent.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Steal any thing from anybody living.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Not from thy master.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: That's mine own body.
And must not be.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The boy mends mightily.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A rich man, that like snow, heaps up his moneys
I have a kind of pious zeal to meet still;
A fool that not deserves 'em, I take pity on,
For fear he should run mad, and so I ease him.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Excellent boy, and able to instruct me,
Of my own nature just.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I scorn all hazard,
And on the edge of danger I do best sir,
I have a thousand faces to deceive,
And to those twice so many tongues to flatter,
An impudence no brass was ever tougher,
And for my conscience.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Peace, I ha' found a jewel,
A jewel all the Indies cannot match,
And thou shalt feel —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This title, and I ha' done sir;
I never can confess, I ha' that spell on me;
And such rare modesties before a magistrate,
Such innocence to catch a judge, such ignorance.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I'll learn of thee, thou art my own, come boy
I'll give thee action presently.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Have at you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What must I call thee

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Snap sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis most natural
A name born to thee, sure thou art a fairy,
Show but thy skill, and I shall make thee happy.
sp.stage: Enter lady, nurse, mistress Newlove, Tebia.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Where be these knaves? who strews up all the liveries,
Is the bride's bed made?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Yes madam and a bell
Hung under it artificially.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Out knave out
Must we have larums now?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: A little warning
That we may know when to begin our healths madam,
The justice is a kind of old jade madam,
That will go merriest with a bell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: All the house drunk.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: This is a day of jubilee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Are the best hangings up, and the plate set out?
Who makes the posset, nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: The dairy maid,
And she'll put that in will make him caper:
Well madam, well, you might ha' chose another,
A handsomer for your years.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Peace he is rich nurse,
He is rich, and that's beauty.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I am sure he is rotten,
Would he had been hanged when he first saw her. Termagant!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What an angry quean is this, where,
Who looks to him?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He is very merry madam
M. Wildbrain, has him in hand, ith' bottom o'th cellar
He sighs and tipples.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Alas good gentleman,
My hearts sore for thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sorrow must have his course, sirrah
Give him some sack to dry up his remembrance,
How does the bridegroom, I am afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He is a trim youth to be tender of, hemp take him.
Must my sweet new blown rose find such a winter
Before her spring be near.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou art foolish.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: And dances like a town top: and reels, and hobbles.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas, good gentleman, give him not much wine.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: He shall ha' none by my consent.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Are the women comforting my daughter?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Yes, yes, madam,
And reading to her a pattern of true patience,
They read and pray for her too.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They had need,
Ye had better marry her to her grave a great deal:
There will be peace and rest, alas poor gentlewoman,
Must she become a nurse now in her tenderness?
Well madam well my heart bleeds.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou art a fool still

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Pray heaven I be.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And an old fool to be vexed thus.
'Tis late she must to bed, go knave be merry,
drink for a boy, away to all your charges.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Do as thou wot, but if thou dost refuse it
Thou art the stupidest ass, there's no long arguing,
Time is too precious Frank.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am hot with wine,
And apt now to believe, but if thou dost this
Out of a villainy, to make me wrong her,
As thou art prone enough.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Does she not love thee?
Did she not cry down right e'en now to part with thee?
Had she not swooned if I had not caught her?
Canst thou have more?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I must confess all this.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Do not stand prating, and misdoubting, casting,
If she go from thee now, she's lost for ever;
Now now she's going, she that loves thee going,
She whom thou lov'st .

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray let me think a little.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: There is no leisure; think when thou hast embraced her
Can she imagine thou didst ever honour her,
Ever believe thy oaths, that tamely sufferest
An old dry ham of horse flesh to enjoy her
Enjoy her maiden head; take but that from her
That we may tell posterity a man had it,
A handsome man, a gentleman, a young man,
To save the honour of our house, the credit,
'Tis no great matter I desire.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I hear you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Free us both from the fear of breeding fowls
And ophs, got by this shadow: we talk too long.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She is going now to bed, among the women
What opportunity can I have to meet her?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Let me alone, hast thou a will? speak soundly,
Speak discreetly, speak home and handsomely,
Is't not pity, nay misery, nay infamy to leave
So rare a pie to be cut up by a rascal.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I will go presently, now, now, I stay thee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Such a dainty doe, to be taken
By one that knows not neck beef from a pheasant,
Nor cannot relish bragget from Ambrosia.
Is it not conscience.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes, yes, now I feel it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A meritorious thing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Good father wild-goose,
I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Come then follow me
And pluck a man's heart up, I'll lock thee privately
Where she alone shall presently pass by,
None near to interupt thee but be sure;

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I shall be sure enough, lead on, and crown me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No wringings in your mind now as you love me.
sp.stage: Enter lady, Maria, justice. gent. nurse, Newlove.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis time you were a-bed .

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: I prithee sweet heart
Consider my necessity, why art sad?
I must tell you a tale in your ear anon.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Of Tom thumb.
I believe that will prove your stiffest story.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: I pity the young wench.
And so do I too.
Come, old sticks take fire.
But the plague is, he'll burn out instantly;
Give him another cup.
Those are but flashes,
A run of sack wonot set him high enough.
Will ye to bed?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I must.
Come have a good heart,
And win him like a bowl to lie close to you,
Make your best use.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Nay prithee duck go instantly,
I'll dance a jig or two to warm my body.

sp.speaker: Wild
sp.l: 'Tis almost midnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Prithee to bed Maria.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Go you afore, and let the ladies follow,
And leave her to her thoughts a while, there must be
A time of taking leave of the same fooleries
Bewailing others maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Come then,
We'll wait in the next room.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Do not tarry
For if thou dost, by my troth I shall fall asleep mall.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do, do, and dream of dotterels, get you to bed quickly
And let us ha' no more stir, come no crying
'Tis too late now, carry yourself discreetly,
The old thief loves thee dear, that's the benefit.
For the rest you must make your own play, nay not that way,
They'll pull ye all to pieces, for your whim whams,
Your garters and your gloves, go modestly
And privately steal to bed, 'tis very late mall,
For if you go by them such a new alarm.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know not which way to avoid 'em.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This way
This through the cloisters: and so steal to bed,
When you are there once, all will separate
And give ye rest, I came out of my pity
To show you this.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Here's the keys
Go presently and lock the doors fast after ye,
That none shall follow.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Goodnight sweet cousin,
A good, and sweet night, or I'll curse thee Frank.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She stays long, sure young wild-goose has abused me,
He has made sport wi'me, I may yet get out again,
And I may see his face once more, I ha' soul intentions,
But they are drawn on by a fouler dealing.
Hark, hark, it was the door,
Something comes this way, wondrous still, and stealing
may be some walking spirit to affright me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O heaven my fortune.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis her voice, stay.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Save me
Bless me you better powers.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am no devil.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You're little better to disturb me now.

sp.speaker: Prostitute
sp.l: My name is Hartlove

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Fie, fie, worthy friend,
Fie noble sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I must talk farther with ye
You know my fair affection.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So preserve it,
You know I am married now, for shame be civiller,
Not all the earth shall make me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray walk this way,
And if you ever loved me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Take heed Frank
How you divert that love to hate, go home prithee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Shall he enjoy that sweet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay pray unhand me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: He that ne'er felt what love was.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Then I charge you
Stand further off.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am tame, but let me walk wi'ye,
Talk but a minute.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So your talk be honest
And my untainted honour suffer not
I'll walk a turn or two.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Give me your hand then.
sp.stage: Enter Wildbrain, justice, lady, nurse, gent. women, Newlove.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: She's not in her chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: She is not here.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And I'll tell you what I dreamed

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Give me a torch.

sp.speaker: 1 and G.
sp.l: Be not too hasty sir.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay let him go,
for if my dream be true, he must be speedy,
He will be tricked, and blazed else.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: As I am a woman
I cannot blame her if she take her liberty,
Would she would make thee cuckold thou old bully,
A notorious cuckold for tormenting her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll hang her then.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I'll bless her then, she does justice,
Is this old stinking dogs flesh for her diet?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prithee honest nurse do not fret too much
For fear I dream you'll hang yourself too.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: The cloister?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Such was my fancy, I do not say 'tis true,
Nor do I bid you be too confident.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where are the keys, the keys I say.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I dreamed she had 'em to lock herself in.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: What a devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No harm good nurse be patient

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: They are not in the window, where they use to be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What foolish dreams are these?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I hope so.
If you be not mad, I'll do my best to make ye.
This is some trick.
I smell the wild-goose.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, come quickly I beseech you,
Quick as you can, this may be your case gentlemen.
And bring some lights, some lights.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Move faster, faster, you'll come too late else.
I'll stay behind and pray for ye, I had rather she were dishonest,
Than thou shouldst have her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're most unmanly, yet I have some breath lest;
And this steel to defend me, come not near me,
For if you offer but another violence,
As I have life I'll kill you, if I miss that,
Upon my own heart will I execute,
and let that fair belief out, I had of you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Most virtuous maid, I have done, forgive my follies:
Pardon, oh pardon, I now see my wickedness,
And what a monstrous shape it puts upon me,
On your fair hand I seal.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Down with the door.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We are betrayed, o Frank, Frank.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll die for ye
Rather than you shall suffer, I'll — —

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Now enter.
Enter sweet gentlemen, mine eyes, mine eyes,
O how my head aches.
Is it possible?
Hold her, she sinks.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A plot upon my honour
To poison my fair name, a studied villainy,
Farewell, as I have hope of peace, I am honest,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My brains, my brains, my monstrous brains, they bud sure.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She is gone, she is gone.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A handsome riddance of her.
Would I could as easily lose her memory.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Is this the sweet of marriage, have I bred thee
For this reward?
Hold, hold, he's desperate too.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Be sure ye hold him fast, we'll bind him over
To the next sessions, and if I can I'll hang him.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay then I'll live to be a terror to thee,
Sweet virgin rise farewell: heaven has thy beauty,
That's only fit for heaven. I'll live a little
To find the villain out that wrought this injury,
And then most blessed soul, I'll climb up to thee.
Farewell, I feel myself another creature.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O misery of miseries.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I told ye madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Carry her in, you will pay back her portion.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: No not a penny, pay me back my credit
And I'll condition weigh.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: A sad wedding
her grave must be her bridal bed, o Mall,
Would I had wed thee to thy own content
Than I had had thee still.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am mad, farewell,
Another wanton wife will prove a hell.

sp.stage: Enter Tom Lurch. and his boy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I have walked through all the lodgings.
A silence as if death dwelled there inhabits.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What hast thou seen?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Naught but a sad confusion thing
Every left in such a loose disorder
That were there twenty thieves, they would be laden.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, I like thy care, but 'tis strange
A wedding night should be so solitary.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Certainly there is some cause, some death or sickness
Is fallen suddenly upon some friend,
Or some strange news is come.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Are they all a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I think so, and sound asleep , unless it be
Some women that keep watch in a low parlour,
And drink, and weep, I know not to what end.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Where's all the plate?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why locked up in that room.
I saw the old lady, ere she went to bed
Put up her plate, and some of the rich hangings
In a small long chest, her chain and rings are there too,
It stands close by the table on a form.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Twas a good notice, didst thou see the men.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I saw them sad too, and all take their leaves,
But what they said I was too far to hear sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis daintily discovered, we shall certainly
Have a most prosperous night, which way.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A close one,
A back door, that the women have left open,
To go in and out to fetch necessaries,
Close on the garden side.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I love thy diligence,
Wert thou not fearful.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fearful? I'll be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Say they had spied thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I was then determined
To have cried down right too, and have kept 'em company,
As one that had an interest in their sadness,
Or made an errand to I know not whom sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My dainty boy, let us discharge, that plate
Makes a perpetual motion in my fingers
Till I have fast hold of it.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Pray be wise sir, do't handsomely, be not greedy,
Let's handle it with such an excellence
As if we would bring thieving into honour:
We must disguise, to fright these reverend watches.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still my blessed boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And clear the room of drunken jealousies,
The chest is of some weight, and we may make
Such noise ith' carriage we may be snapped.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come open, here's a devil's face.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, no, sir, we'll have no shape so terrible,
We will not do the devil so much pleasure,
To have him face our plot.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A winding sheet then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That's too cold a shift,
I would not wear the reward of my wickedness,
I wonder you are an old thief, and no cunninger,
Where's the long cloak?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Give me the turban
And the false beard, I hear some coming this way,
Stoop, stoop, and let me sit upon your shoulders
And now as I direct: stay let 'em enter,
And when I touch move forward, make no noise.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: O 'tis a sad time, all the burned wine is drunk Nick.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: We may thank your dry chaps for't, the canaries gone too
No substance for a sorrowful mind to work upon,
I cannot mourn in beer, if she should walk now
As discontented spirits are wont to do.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: And meet us in the cellar.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: What sense have we with single beer against her?
What heart can we defy the devil with?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: The march beer's open.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A fortification of march beer will do well,
I must confess 'tis a most mighty armour,
For I presume I cannot pray.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Why Nicholas?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: We coachmen have such tumbling faiths, no prayers
Can go an even pace.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Hold up your candle.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Verily nurse, I have cried so much
For my young mistress, that is mortified,
That if I have not more sack to support me,
I shall even sleep, heigho, for another flagon;
These burials and christenings are the mournfulst matters,
And they ask more drink.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Drink to a sad heart's needful.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Mine's ever sad, for I am ever dry nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Methinks the light burns blue, I prithee snuff it
There's a thief in't I think.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: There may be one near it.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: What's that that moves there, ith' name of — Nicholas?
That thing that walks.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Would I had a ladder to behold it,
Mercy upon me, the ghost of one oth' guard sure,
'Tis the devil by his claws, he smells of brimstone,
Sure he farts fire, what an earthquake I have in me;
Out with thy prayer book nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: It fell i'the frying-pan, and the cats eat it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I have no power to pray, it grows still longer,
'Tis steeple high now, and it sails away nurse,
let's call the butler up, for he speaks Latin,
And that will daunt the devil: I am blasted,
My bellies grown to nothing.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Fie, fly, Toby.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: So let them go, and whilst they are astonished
Let us presently upon the rest now suddenly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Off, off, and up again, when we are near the parlour,
Art sure thou knowest the chest?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Though it were ith' dark sir,
I can go to't.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: On then and be happy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: How my haunches quake? is the thing here still
Now can I outdo any button maker, at his own trade,
I have fifteen fits of an ague, nurse, 'tis gone I hope
The hard hearted woman has left me alone. Nurse —
And she knows too I ha' but a lean conscience to keep me company.
The devils among 'em in the parlour sure,
The ghost three storeys high, he has the nurse sure,
He is boiling of her bones now, hark how she whistles:
There's gentlewomen within too, how will they do?
I'll to the cook, for he was drunk last night,
And now he is valiant, he's a kin toth' devil too
And fears no fire,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No light?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: None left sir,
They are gone, and carried all the candles with 'em
Their fright is infinite, let's make good use on't
We must be quick sir, quick, or the house will rise else.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Was this the chest?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: There was two of 'em
Or I mistake.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know the right, no stay sir,
Nor no discourse, but to our labour lustily,
Put to your strength and make as little noise,
then presently out at: the back door.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come boy.
Come happy child and let me hug thy excellence.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.l: What thousand noises pass through all the rooms?
What cries and hurries? sure the devils drunk.
And tumbles through the house, my villainies
That never made me apprehend before
Danger or fear, a little now molest me;
My cousin's death sits heavy o'my conscience,
Would I had been half hanged when I hammered it.
I aimed at a living divorce, not a burial
That Frank might have had some hope: hark still
In every room confusion, they are all mad,
Most certain all stark mad within the house
A punishment inflicted for my lewdness,
That I might have the more sense of my mischief
And run the more mad too, my aunt is hanged sure,
Sure hanged herself, or else the fiend has fetched her;
I heard a hundred cries, the devil, the devil,
Then roaring and then tumbling, all the chambers
Are a mere Babell, or another bedlam.
What should I think? I shake myself too:
Can the devil find no time, but when we are merry,
Here's something comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: O that I had some company,
I care not what they were, to ease my misery,
To comfort me,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Again? nay then receive

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Hold, hold I am no fury.
The merchant's wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Are ye a man? pray heaven you be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Alas I have met sir
The strangest things too night.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why do you stare.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Pray comfort me, and put your candle out
for if I see the spirit again I die fort.
And hold me fast, for I shall shake to pieces else.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I'll warrant you, I'll hold ye,
Hold ye as tenderly; I have put the light out,
Retire into my chamber, there I'll watch we ye,
I'll keep you from all frights.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: And will ye keep me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Keep you as secure lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: You must not wrong me then, the devil will have us.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No, no, I'll love you, then the devil will fear us.
For he fears all that love, pray come in quickly,
For this is the malicious house he walks in,
The hour he blasts sweet faces, lame the limbs in,
Depraves the senses, now within this half hour
He will have power to turn all citizens wives
Into strange creatures, owls, and long-tailed monkey's
Jays, pies, and parrots, quickly, I smell his brimstone.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: It comes again I am gone, shift for yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Sure this whole night is nothing but illusion,
Here's nothing comes, all they are mad, dammed devil
To drive her back again, 't had been thy policy
To have let us alone, we might have done some fine thing
To have made thy hell-hood laugh, 'tis a dainty wench
If I had her again, not all your fellow goblins
Nor all their claws should scratch her hence, I'll stay still,
May be her fright will bring her back again,
Yet I will hope.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I can find no bed, nobody , nor no chamber,
Sure they are all ith' cellar, and I cannot find that neither,
I am led up, and down like a tame ass, my light's out
And I grope up and down like blindman buff
And break my face, and break my pate.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It comes again sure
I see the shadow, I'll have faster hold now,
Sure she is mad, I long to lie with a madwoman,
She must needs have rare new tricks.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I hear one whisper
if it be the devil now to allure me into his clutches,
For devils have a kind of tone like crickets,
I have a glimpse of her guise, 'tis she would steal by me,
But I'll stand sure.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I have but a dram of wit left,
And that's even ready to run, o for my bed now.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: She named a bed, I like that, she repents sure,
Where is she now.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Who's that.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Are you there, in, in, in presently.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I feel his talents through me
'Tis an old haggard devil, what will he do with me?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Let me kiss thee first, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A lecherous devil.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What a hairy whore 'tis, sure she has a muffler.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: If I should have a young Satan by him, for I dare not deny him,
In what case were I? who durst deliver me?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: 'Tis but my fancy, she is the same, in quickly, gently my
Sweet girl.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet devil be good to me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Where's my love boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She's coming with a candle
To see our happy prize.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am cruel weary.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot blame ye, plate is very heavy
To carry without light or help.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The fear too
At every stumble to be discovered boy,
At every cough to raise a constable,
Well, we'll be merry now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We have some reason;
Things compassed without feat or eminent danger
Are too luxurious sir to live upon.
Money and wealth got thus are as full venture,
And carry in their natures as much merit
As his, that digs 'em out oth' mine, they last too
seasoned with doubts and dangers most deliciously,
Riches that fall upon us are too ripe,
And dull our appetites.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Most learned child.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: You're welcome, where have you left it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the next room, hard by.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Is it plate all.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All, all, and jewels, I am monstrous weary,
Prithee let's go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Prithee let's see it first.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: To morrows a new sweet.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Yes to melt it,
But let's agree tonight , how it shall be handled
I'll have a new gown.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Shalt have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: And such a riding suit as mistress Newlove's,
What though I be no gentlewoman born,
I hope I may achieve it by my carriage.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou sayst right.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: You promised me a horse too, and a lackey.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou shalt have horses six, and a postilion.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: That will be stately sweet heart, a postilion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay we'll be in fashion, he shall ride before us
In winter, with as much dirt would damp a musket,
The inside of our coach shall be of scarlet.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: That will be dear.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: There is a dye projecting
Will make it cheap wench, come thou shalt have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Where is this chest, I long sweet to behold
Our Jndies.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Mistress let's melt it first, and then 'tis fit
You should dispose it, then 'tis safe from danger.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: I'll be a loving mistress to my boy too.
Now fetch it in and let's rejoice upon't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hold your light mistress, we may see to enter.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Ha what's here ? call you this a chest?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We ha' missed sir.
Our haste and want of light made us mistake?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: A very coffin.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How, a coffin? Boy, 'tis very like one.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The devil owed us a shame, and now he has paid us.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Is this your treasure?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Bury me alive in't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It may be there is no room.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Nay, I will search it,
I'll see what wealth's within, — — a woman's face,
And a fair woman's.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot tell sir,
Belike this was the sadness that possessed 'em;
The plate stood next, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I shake, I shake boy, what a cold sweat —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This may work, what will become on's sir?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: She is cold, dead cold: d'ye find 'your conscience,
D'ye bring your Gillians hither — nay, she's punished,
Your concealed love's cased up?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis Maria, the very same, the bride, new horror!

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: These are fine tricks, you hope she's in a sound,
But I'll take order she shall ne'er recover
To bore my nose, come, take her up and bury her
Quickly, or I'll cry out; take her up instantly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Be not so hasty fool, that may undo us;
We may be in for murder so; be patient,
Thou seest she's dead, and cannot injure thee.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: I am sure she shall not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be not sir dejected,
Too much a strange mistake! this had not been else,
It makes me almost weep to think upon't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What an unlucky thief am I?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: I'll no considering, either bestir yourself, or —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Let it not stay to smell then, I will not
Endure the stink of a rival.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Would 'twere there again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We must bury her.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But where o'th sudden, or with what providence,
that no eyes watch us.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Take a spade and follow me.
The next fair ground we meet, make the church yard;
As I live, I'll see her lodged.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It must be so,
How heavy my heart is, I ha' no life left.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am past thinking too, no understanding,
That I should miss the right chest.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The happy chest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That, which I saw and marked too.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Well passion won't help us,
Had I twenty falls for this?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Twas my fault sir.
And twenty thousand fears for this, oth' devil,
Now could I curse, well, we have her now,
And must dispose her.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Hang both for two blind buzzards, here's a spade
Quickly or I'll call the neighbours.
There's no remedy,
Would the poor hungry prisoners had this pastry.
sp.stage: Enter justice, and a servant with a light.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Twas a strange mischance sir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Mischance, sayest? No 'twas happiness to me,
There's so much charge saved, I have her portion,
I'll marry twenty more on such conditions.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Did it not trouble you sir,
To see her dead?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not much, I thank my conscience;
I was tormented till that happened, furies
Were in my brain to think myself a cuckold
At that time of the night:
When I come home, I charge you shut my doors,
Locks, bolts, and bars, are little enough to secure me,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why, and please you?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Fool to ask that question;
To keep out women, I expect her mother
Will visit me with her clamours, o I hate
their noise, and do abhor the whole sex heartily;
They are all walking devils, harpies, I will study
A week together how to rail sufficiently,
Upon 'em all, and that I may be furnished,
Thou shalt buy all the railing books and ballads,
That malice hath invented against women,
I will read nothing else, and practise 'em,
Till I grow fat with curses.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: If you'll go
To th'charge, let me alone to find you books.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: They come near us.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Where? hold up the torch knave.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Did you hear nothing? 'tis a —

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Why dost make a stand?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where, where, dost see any thing?
We are hard by the churchyard, and I was never
Valiant at midnight in such irksome places;
They say ghosts walk sometimes, hark, d'ye hear nothing?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: No further, dig here, and lay her in quickly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What light is that boy, we shall be discovered;
Set the coffin up an end, and get behind me,
There's no avoiding.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Where's that groan? I begin to be afraid.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What shall we do sir?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: We are almost at home now, thou must go forward;
Perhaps 'twas my imagination.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know him too, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O sir, a ghost, the very ghost of mistress Bride.
I have no power to run away.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Cursed ghost; bless me, preserve me,
I do command thee whatsoe'er thou art,
I do conjure thee leave me; do not fright me;
If thou beest a devil vex me not so soon,
If thou beest
the spirit of my wife.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thy wife.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I shall be tormented.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thy abused wife, that cannot peaceably
Enjoy her death, thou hast an evil conscience.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Among thy other sins which black thy soul,
Call to thy mind thy vow made to another,
Whom thou hast wronged, and make her satisfaction
Now I am dead, thou perjured man, or else
A thousand black tormentors shall pursue thee,
Until thou leap into eternal flames;
Where gold which thou adorest here on earth
Melted, the fiends shall pour into thy throat;
For this time pass, go home, and think upon me,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A way.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There are more spirits.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thank you dear wife,
I'll bestow twenty nobles of a tomb for thee,
Thou shalt not walk and catch cold after death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: So, so, they're gone, 'twas my ingenious rascal:
But how dost know he made vows to another?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I overheard the women talk tonight on't;
But now let's lose no time sir, pray let's bury
This gentlewoman, where's my mistress?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Here, I durst not tarry.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: We ha' so cozened the old forty i'th hundred,
And the devil hinder him not, he'll go a pilgrimage;
But come, about our business, set her down again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: She groans, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Again, she stirs.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Let's fly, or else we shall be torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And you be good at that, bury yourself,
Or let the sexton take ye for his fee,
Away boy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am very cold, dead cold;
Where am I? What's this? A coffin? where have I been?
Mercy defend me: ha, I do remember
I was betrayed, and swooned; my heart aches,
I am wondrous hungry too, dead bodies eat not;
Sure I was meant for burial, I am frozen;
Death, like a cake of ice dwells round about me,
Darkness spreads o'er the world too, where? what path,
Best providence direct me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou art the most unfortunate fellow;

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why aunt, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: The most malicious varlet,
Thy wicked head never at rest, but hammering,
And hatching hellish things, and to no purpose,
So thou mayst have thy base will.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why do you rail thus?
Cannot a scurvy accident fall out,
But I must be at one end on't?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou art at both ends.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Cannot young sullen wenches play the fools,
And marry, and die, but I must be the agent?
All that I did (And if that be an injury,
Let the world judge it) was but to persuade her
(And as I take it) I was bound to it too,
To make the reverend coxcomb her husband cuckold:
What else could I advise her, was there harm i'this?
You are of years, and have run through experience,
Would you be content if you were young again,
To have a continual cough grow to your pillow,
A rottenness, that vaults are perfumes to
Hang in your roof, and like a fog infect you;
Anointed hams to keep his hinges turning
Reek ever in your nose, and twenty nightcaps,
With twenty several sweats.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Some Jew, some justice,
a thousand heathen smells to say truth madam,
And would you mellow my young pretty mistress
In such a mis-ken?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sirrah,
Where's the body of my girl?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I know not,
I am no conjurer, you may look the body,
I was like to be stolen away myself, the spirit
Had like to ha' surprised me in the shape of a woman,
Of a young woman, and you know those are dangerous.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: So had I madam, simply though I stand here,
I had been ravished too: I had twenty spirits
In every corner of the house a fiend met me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You lie like rascals,
Was mistress Newlove such a spirit sir
To fright your worship;
Well, I discharge you sir, you're now at liberty,
Live where you please, and do what pranks you fancy,
You know your substance, though you are my nephew,
I am no way bound sir to protect your mischief;
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Farewell good aunt, I thank you,
Adieu honest Nick, the devil if he have power,
Will persecute your old bones, for this marriage,
Fare well mistress win.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: And shall we part with dry lips;
Shall we that have been fellow devils together
Flinch for an old woman's fart?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine time a night too, but we must part Nick.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall we never ring again? never toss the tenor,
And roll the changes in a cup of claret?
You shall not want whate'er I lay my hands on,
As I am sure Automedon the coachman,
Shall be distributed; bear up, I say, hang sorrow,
Give me that bird abroad that lives at pleasure,
Same the butlers true, the cook a reverend Trojan,
The falconer shall sell his hawks, and swear they were rotten,
There be some wand'ring spoons, that may be met with,
I'll pawn a coach horse, peace, utter no sentences.
The harness shall be used in our wars also;
Or shall I drive her (Tell me but your will now,
Say but the word) over some rotten bridge,
Or by a marl pit side, she may slip in daintily,
Let me alone for myself.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, farewell Toby,
Farewell spiny Nicholas, no such thing,
There be ways i'the world, if you see me
A day or two hence, may be we'll crack a quart yet,
And pull a bell, commend to the household;
Nay, cry not Toby 'twill make thy head giddy.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet master Wildbrain.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No more Toby go, the times may alter —
But where's the corse of my dead cousin,
(If she be dead) I hoped 'thad but dissembled
That sits heavy here: Toby, honest Toby,
Lend me thy lantern, I forgotten 'twas dark,
I had need look to my ways now.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Take a lodging with me tonight in the stable,
And ride away tomorrow with one of the horses
Next your heart, pray do.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, good night good neighbour Toby, I will wander,
I scorn to submit myself, ere I have rambled,
But whether, or with what, that's more material;
No matter, and the worst come it is but stealing,
And my aunt won't see me hanged for her own credit,
And farewell in a halter costs me nothing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The night, and all the evils the night covers,
The goblins, hags, and the black spawn of darkness
Cannot fright me, no death, I dare thy cruelty,
For I am weary both of life and light too;
Keep my wit's heaven, they say spirits appear
To melancholy minds, and the graves open,
I would fain see the fair Maria's shadow,
But speak unto her spirit ere I died,
But ask upon my knees a mercy from her:
I was a villain, but her wretched kinsman,
That set his plot, shall with his heart blood satisfy
Her injured life and honour, what lights this?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It is but melancholy walking thus;
The tavern doors are barricadoed too,
Where I might drink till morn, in expectation;
I cannot meet the watch neither; nothing in
The likeness of a constable, whom I might
In my distress abuse, and so be carried,
For want of other lodging to the counter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis his voice, fate, I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha, who's that, and thou beest a man speak?
Frank heartlove, then I bore my destinies,
Thou art the man of all the world I wished for;
My aunt has turned me out a doors, she has,
At this unchristian hour, and I do walk,
Methinks , like Guido Faux with my dark lantern,
Stealing to set the town a fire; ith' country
I should be ta'en for William o'the wisp,
Or Robin Goodfellow, and how dost Frank?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The worse for you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come, thar't a fool, art going to thy lodging?
I'll lie with thee tonight , and tell thee storeys,
How many devils we ha' met withal;
Our house is haunted Frank, whole legions,
I saw fifty for my share.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Didst not fright 'em?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How, fright 'em? no, they frighted me sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thou hadst wickedness enough to make them stare,
And be afraid o'thee, malicious devil;
And draw thy sword, for by Maria's soul;
I will not let thee scape to do more mischief.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou art mad, what dost mean?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: To kill thee, nothing else will ease my anger,
The injury is fresh, I bleed with all,
Nor can that word express it, there's no peace in't,
Nor must it be forgiven but in death;
therefore call up thy valour if thou'st any,
And summon up thy spirits to defend thee;
Thy heart must suffer for thy damned practises,
Against thy noble cousin, and my innocence.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hold, hear a word; did I do any thing
But for your good, that you might have her,
That in that desperate time I might redeem her,
Although with show of loss.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Out ugly villain,
Fling on her the most hated name of whore
To the world's eye, and face it out in courtesy,
Bring him to see't, and make me drunk to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I hear some voices this way.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No more, if you can pray, do it as you fight.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What new frights oppose me? I have heard that tongue.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis my fortune,
You could not take me in a better time sir,
I ha' nothing to lose, but the love I lent thee,
My life my sword protect.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know 'em both, but to prevent their ruins,
Must not discover — — stay men most desperate;
The mischief you are forward to commit
Will keep me from my grave, and tie my spirit
To endless troubles else.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis her ghost. Fr. Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Hear me both, each wound you make
Runs through my soul, and is a new death to me,
Each threatening danger will affright my rest;
Look on me Hartlove, and my kinsman view me;
Was I not late in my unhappy marriage,
Sufficient miserable? full of all misfortunes?
But you must add with your most impious angers
Unto my sleeping dust this insolence?
Would you teach time to speak eternally
Of my disgraces; make records to keep 'em,
Keep them in brass? fight then, and kill my honour;
Fight deadly both, and let your bloody swords,
Through my revived, and reeking infamy
(That never shall be purged) find your own ruins:
Hartlove, I loved thee once, and hoped again
In a more blessed love to meet thy spirit,
If thou killest him, thou art a murderer,
And murder shall never inherit heaven:
My time is come, my concealed grave expects me,
Farewell, and follow not, your feet are bloody,
And will pollute my peace: I hope they are melted,
This is my way sure.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Stay blessed souls.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Would she had come sooner, and ha' saved some blood.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Dost bleed?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Yes certainly, I can both see and feel it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now I well hope it is not dangerous;
Give me thy hand, as far as honour guides me,
I'll know thee again.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I thank thee heartily;
I know not where to get a surgeon;
This vision troubles me, sure she is living,
And I was foolish blind, I could not find it;
I bleed apace still, and my heart grows heavy,
If I go far I faint, I'll knock at this house,
They may be charitable, would 'twere perfect day.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: 'Tis not he? What would you sir?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I would crave a little rest lady,
And for my hurts some surgery, I am a gentleman
That fortune of a fight —

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: A handsome gentleman,
Alas he bleeds, a very handsome gentleman,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A sweet young wench, beshrew my heart a fair one;
Fortune has made me some recompense.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Pray come in, the air is hurtful for you;
Pray let me lead you, I'll have a bed for you presently,
I'll be your surgeon too, alas sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I feel no hurts, the morning comes too fast now.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: Softly I beseech you.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He is not up yet madam, what meant you
To come forth so early?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You block head;
Your eyes are sowed up still, they cannot see
When it is day: o my poor Maria,
where be the women?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: They said they would follow us.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He shall not laugh thus at my misery,
And kill my child, and steal away her body,
And keep her portion too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Let him be hanged fort,
You have my voice.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: These women not come yet?
A son in law, I'll keep a conjurer,
But I'll find out his knavery.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Do, and I'll help him;
And if he were here this whip should conjure him,
Here's a capias, and it catch hold on's breech,
I'd make him soon believe the devil were there.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: An old usurer.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He married the money, that's all he looked for,
For your daughter, let her sink or swim.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll swim him;
This is his house, I wonder they stay thus,
That we might rail him out on's wits.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: They'll come,
Fear not madam, and bring clappers with 'em,
Or some have lost their old wont, I have heard
No disparagement to your ladyship, some o'their tongues
Like Tom a Lincoln three miles off.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O fie,
How tedious are they?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: What and we lost no time,
You and I shall make a shift to begin with him,
And tune our instruments, till the comfort come
To make up the full noise, I'll knock.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Who's that? raps so saucily?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: 'Tis I, Toby, come down, or else we'll fetch you down,
Alas, this is but the saunce-bell, here's a gentlewoman
Will ring you another peal, come down, I say.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Some new fortifications, look to my doors,
Put double bars, I will not have her enter,
Nor any of her tribe, they come to terrify me?
Keep out her tongue too if you can.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I hear you,
and I will send my tongue up to your worship,
The echo of it shall fly o'er the street;
My daughter, that thou killed'st with kindness (Jew)
That thou betrayd'st to death, thou double Jew,
And after stolest her body.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Jew's too good for him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I defy you both;
Thy daughter played the villain and betrayed me.
Betrayed my honour.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Honour, rascal,
And let that bear an action, I'll try it with thee,
Honour?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: O reprobate!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou musty justice,
Buy an honourable halter, and hang thyself.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A worshipful ropes end is too good for him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Get honour that way, thou wot die a dog else.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Come and be whipped first.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Where is her porrion.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where I'll keep it safely.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Traitor, thou shalt not keep it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: More of the kennel? put more bolts to'th doors there,
And arm yourselves, hell is broke loose upon us.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am glad you're come, we'll blow the house down.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O nurse, I have such cause —

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Villain, viper, although you had no cause, we are bound
To help.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Yes, and believe, we come not here to examine,
And if you please we'll fire the house.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Call the constable.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A charitable motion, fire is comfortable.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No, no, we'll only let him know our minds,
We will commit no outrage, he's a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Give me my musket.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Where's my daughter's body,
That I may bury it?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Speak, or we'll bury thee,

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Alive we'll bury thee, speak old iniquity.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Bury him alive by all means for a testimony.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Their voices make my house reel, o for officers,
I am in a dream, thy daughter's spirit
Walks a nights, and troubles all the neighbours;
Go hire a conjurer, I'll say no more.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: The law shall say more.

sp.speaker: Woman and nur.
sp.l: We are witnesses,
And if thou beest not hanged —

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Buy a book of good manners,
A short book of good manners.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Buy a ballad, a ballad of the maid was got with child.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: That might ha' been my case last night,
I'll have't whate'er it cost me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A ballad of the witches hanged at Ludlow.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I will have that too;
There was an aunt of mine, I think amongst 'em,
I would be glad to hear her testament.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A new book of women.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The thunders laid, how they stare at him.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A new book of fools, a strange book,
Very strange fools.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I'll owe thee a good turn whate'er thou art.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of walking spirits.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That I like not.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Nor I, they walked me the fool's morris.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of wicked women.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That's well thought on.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Of rude malicious women, of proud women,
Of scolding women, we shall ne'er get in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A ballad of wronged maids.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll buy that.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A little, very little book
Of good and godly women, a very little one,
So little, you may put it in a nutshell.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: With a small print, that nobody can read it.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Peace sirrah, or I'll tear your books.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Open the door, and let him in, I love him.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of evil magistrates.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I marry, d'ye here that justice.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And their eviller wives,
That we are their places in their petticoats.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: D'ye you hear that lady.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A book new printed, against playing,
Dancing, masking, maypoles; a zealous brother's book,
And full of fables.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Another book of women, of mad women,
Women that were born in march.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Are you got in?
We would ha' pulled your knaves hide else; this fellow
Was sent to abuse us, but we shall have time
To talk more with this justice.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Farewell madam, as you like this come visit me again,
You and your treble strings, now scold your hearts out —

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Shall he carry it thus away?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Go to the judge, and what you'll have us swear —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I thank ye heartily,
I'll keep that for the last, I will go home,
And leave him to his conscience for a while,
If it sleep long, I'll wake it with a vengeance.
What book has he given thee?
A dainty book, a book of the great navy,
Of fifteen hundred ships of cannon proof,
Built upon whales to keep their keels from sinking;
And dragons in 'em, that spit fire ten mile;
And elephants that carry goodly castles.
Dost thou believe it?
Shall we not believe books in print?
I have John tailor's book of hempseed too,
Which for two lines I happened on by chance,
I reverence.
I prithee what are they?
They are so put upon the time, as if
He studied to answer the late Histriomastix,
Talking of change and transformations,
That wittily, and learnedly he bangs him,
So may a Puritans ruff, though starched in print,
Be turned to paper, and a play writ in't:
A play in the Puritans ruff? I'll buy his works for't,
And confute Horace with a water poet:
What haste there, a ballad too?
This? This is a piece of poetry indeed;
What noise is that?
Some cry ith' streets; prithee sing on.
Again, dost not hear? 'tis ith' house certainly?
'Tis a strange noise? and has a tang o'the justice.
Let's see?
sp.stage: Enter the servants bringing in their master bound and gauged.

sp.l: Untie his feet, pull out his gag, he will choke else;
What desperate rogues were these.
Give him fresh air.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I will never study books more;
I am undone, these villains have undone me,
Rifled my desk, they have undone me learnedly;
A fire take all their books, I'll burn my study:
Where were you rascals when the villains bound me,
You could not hear.
He gave us books sir, dainty books to busy us;
And we were reading in that which was the brewhouse;
A great way off, we were singing ballads too,
And could not hear.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: This was a precious thief,
A subtle trick to keep my servants safe.
What ha' you lost fir?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: They ransacked all before my face, and threatened
To kill me, if I coughed, they have a chain,
My rings, my box of casting gold, my purse too,
They robbed me miserably; but that which most grieves me,
They took away some writings; 'twas a rogue
That knew me, and set on by the old lady,
I will indite her for't.
Shall we pursue 'em?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Run, run, cursed rascals,
I am out of my wits, let not a creature in,
No not with necessaries.
We shall be starved.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: I'll buy my meat at window, as they pass by;
I wonot trust my scrivener, he has books too;
And bread I'll ha' flung up; I charge ye all
Burn all the books i th' house.
Your little prayer book?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I'll never pray again, I'll have my doors
Made, up nothing but walls, and thick ones too;
No sound shall tempt me again, remember I
Have forswore books.
If you should be called to take you oath.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I will forswear all oaths, rather than see
A thing but in the likeness of a book:
And I were condemned, I'll rather choose to hang,
Than read again; come in, and search all places,
They may be about the house, were the doors locked?
But the keys in 'em, and if they be gone,
They could not want wit to lock us in sir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Never was man so miserably undone,
I would lose a limb to see their rogueships totter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thy brother's daughter, sayest, and born in Wales?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I have long time desired to see her, and I hope
Your ladyship will not be offended.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I should be happy if she might be serviceable
To you madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Beshrew me, but at first, she took me much,
Is she not like Maria? setting aside
Her language very like her, and I love her
The better for't, I prithee call her hither,
She speaks feat English.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Why, Gwennyth, Gwennyth, du hummah Gwennyth;
She is course madam, after her country guise,
And were she in fine clothes —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll have her handsome:
What part of Wales were you born in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: In abehundis madams.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She speaks that name in Welsh, which we call Breck -

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What can you do? nock.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Her was toe many tings in walls, know not the fashion in London's; her was milk the cows, make seeze and butters, and spin very well the Welsh freeze, her was cook to te mountain cots, and sing very fine Prittish tunes, was mage good ales and breads, and her know to dance on Sundays, marge you now madams.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: A pretty innocence, I do like her infinitely, nurse.
And if I live —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here is Mr. Hartlove, madam, come to see you:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman, prithee admit him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam, I am come to take my last leave.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Of all my home affections, and my friends,
For the interest you had once in Maria,
I would acquaint you when I leave the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Would there were any thing in my poor power
That might divert your will, and make you happy;
I am sure I have wronged her too, but let your pardon
Assure me you are charitable; she's dead
Which makes us both sad: what do you look on?
The likest face —

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Plesse us all, why does that sentilman make such unders and mazements at her, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be not offended maid.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How the wench blushes, she represents Maria's loss to him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Will the sentillman hurt her, pray you be her defences, was have mad phisnomies, is her troubled with lunatics in her praine pans, bless us all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Where had you this face?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Her faces be our none I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I wonot hurt you, all the lineaments
That built Maria up; all those springing beauties
Dwell on this thing, change but her tongue, I know her:
Let me see your hand.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Du Guin, was never thieves, and robberies; here is no sing in her hands warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Trust me, the selfsame white,
And softness, prithee speak our English dialect.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Haleggs? what does her speage hard urds to her, to make poor Gwennyth ridiculous, was no mannerly sentilman to abuse her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By the love,
That everlasting love I bore Maria

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Mariai, her name was Guenith, and good names, was poor else, oman maid, her have no fine kanags to madge her tricksy, yet in her own countries was held a fine ense her can tell her, and honest ense too, marg you dat now, her can keep her little legs close enough warrant her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How prettily this anger shows.
She gabbles innocently.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam, farewell, and all good fortune dwell w'ee,
With me my own affections; farewell maid,
Fair gentle maid.
She sighs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Du cat a whee.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I cannot go, there's somewhat calls me back.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Poor Frank,
How gladly would I entertain thy love,
And meet thy worthy flame, but shame forbids me:
sp.p: If please her ladyships dwell here with Gwennyth, and learn to spin and card rill, to mage flannells, and linsey-wolseys , sall tawg could urds to her ladyship's urships for her.
sp.l: The tears of true affection, woe is me,
Oh cursed love that glories in maids miseries,
And true men's broken hearts.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas I pity him, the wench is rude, and knows you not, forgive her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Wine your nyes pray you, though was porne in walls among craggy rocks, and mountains, yet heart is soft, look you, her can weep too, when her see men mage privy tears and lamentations.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How hard she holds me?
Just as Maria did, weeps the same drops,
Now as I have a living soul, her sigh too;
What shall I think, is not your name Maria,
If it be not, delude me with so much charity
To say it is.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Upon her life, you was mighty deal in love with some podies , your pale seeks and hollow nyes, and pantings upon her bosom, know very well, because look you, her think her honest sentilman, you sall call her Maria.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Good madam, think not ill I am thus saucy.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O no sir, be you not angry with the wench.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am most pleased.
Let's interrupt him, he'll be mad our right else.
Observe a little more.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Would I could in your language beg a kiss.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If her have necessities of a kiss, look you, dear is one in sarities.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let me suffer death,
If in my apprehension, two twinnd cherries
Be more a kin, than her lips to Maria's;
And if this harsh illusion would but leave her,
She were the same; good madam, shall I have
Your consent now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: To give this virgin to me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: She's not mine, this is her kinswoman,
And has more power to dispose; alas, I pity him.
Pray gentlemen prevail with him to go;
More that I wish his comfort than his absence.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have been always kind to me, will you
Deny me your fair chosen.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: 'Twere fit you first obtained her own consent.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He is no friend that wishes my departure,
I do not trouble you.
'Tis not Maria.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Her shadow is enough, I'll dwell with that,
Pursue your own ways, shall we live together?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If her will come tomorrow and tauge to her, her will tell her more of her meanings, and then if her be melancholy, her will sing her a Welsh song too, to make her merries, but Gwennyth was very honest; her was never love but one sentleman, and he was bear her great teale of goodills too, was marry one day, s. Davy her give her five pair of white gloves, if her will dance at her weddings.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: All I am worth,
And all my hopes, this strange voice would forsake her,
For then she should be — prithee stay a little,
Hark in thine ear, dissemble not, but tell me,
And save my life; I know you are Maria:
Speak but as I do ten words to confirm me;
you have an English soul, do not disguise it
From me with these strange accents — she pinched hard
Again, and sighed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What ails the wench?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Why, Gunith.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She's gone too.
Come leave this dream.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A dream? I think so;
But 'twas a pleasing one, now I'll obey,
And forget all these wonders, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Honest Toby?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Wildbrain, — I am glad I ha' met wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why did my aunt send for me?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Your aunt's a mortal, and thinks not on you
For ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Is my cousin alive again?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Neither, and yet we do not hear
That she's buried.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What should make thee glad then?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: What should make me glad? have I not cause,
To see your princely body well, and walk thus,
Look blithe and bonny, and your wardrobe whole still.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The case is clear, and I ha' found a mine,
A perfect Indy, since my aunt cashiered me;
What think'st of this?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: O delicate bells.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou puttest me in mind,
We are to ring anon, I meant to send for thee;
Meet me at the old parish church.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Say no more.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: When thy lady is a-bed , we ha' conspired
A midnight peal for joy.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: If I fail hang me i'th bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And how? and how does my aunt?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: She's up to'th ears in law;
I do so whirl her to the counsellors chambers,
And back again, and bounce her for more money,
And too again, I know not what they do with her,
But she's the merriest thing among these lawdrivers;
And in their studies half a day together;
If they do get her with magna charta, she swears,
By all the ability of her old body,
She will so claw the justice, she will sell
The tiles of the house she vows, and sack out o'th cellar
(That she worships to idolatry) but she'll hang him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I would she could: but hark thee honest Toby,
If a man have a mistress, may we not
Without my aunt's leave, borrow now and than
A coach to tumble in, towards the exchange,
And so forth?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A mistress.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She may be thine when we are married.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Command, I'll carry you both in pomp;
And let my lady go a foot a law-catching,
And exercise her corns: where is she master John?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Shalt see her.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall we ring for her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And drink her health.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Drink stiffly for five hours.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: We'll drink fifteen.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Tonight ? we will ha' twenty torches then,
And through the streets drive on triumphantly;
Triumphantly we'll drive, by my lady's door,
As I am a Christian coachman, I will rattle you
And urine in her porch, and she shall fear me:
If you say more, I shall run mad outright,
I will drink sack and surfeit instantly;
I know not where I am now.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hold for thy buttons sake, the knave's transported.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Jack Wildbrain?

sp.speaker: Wi.
