sp.l: Honest Tom, how thrives the felonious world with thee now?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You look and talk as you were much exalted.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thar't i'the right

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I'll to ll thee first,
I ha' shaken off my aunt, and yet I live still,
And drink, and sing; her house had like to ha' spoiled me;
I keep no hours now;
Nor need any false key
To the old woman's cabinets, I ha' money
Upon my word, and pawn no oaths toth' butler;
No matrimonial protestations;
Our sack possets to the chambermaid,
I praise my fate, there be more ways toth' wood Tom.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Prithee release my wonder.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I'll increase it, wipe thine eyes,
Here is a chain worth money and some man had it,
A foolish diamond, and other trifles —

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The very same, o Gipsy! Infidel!
All that I sweat, and ventured me neck for,
He has got already; who would trust a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This? This is nothing to what I possess
At home.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What home?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A house that shall be nameless;
The mistress of it mine too, such a piece
For flesh and blood, added to that so loving —

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Is, she married?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I know not, nor I care not;
But such a prize, so mounting, so delicious,
Thou wilt run mad, I'll tell thee more hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay, prithee a word more.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I took no pains to find out all this paradise,
My destiny threw me upon't ith' dark, I found it
Wanting a lodging too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Never, never saw her;
But these things happen not in every age,
I cannot stay, if thou wilt meet anon
At my own rendezvous, thou knowest the tavern,
We'll sup together, after that, a company
Of merry lads have made a match to ring.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You keep your exercise, i'the old church?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No other,
There is no music to the bells, we would
Have bonfires if we durst, and thou would come
It shall cost thee nothing Tom, hang pilfering.
And keep me company, in time I may
Show thee my wench too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I cannot promise; but you will be there?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: We'll toss the bells, and make the steeple
Roar boy, but come to supper then.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My hand, and expect me:
Yes I will come or send, and to some purpose;
Art come boy?
sp.stage: Enter boy with gown, beard, and constable's staff.
sp.l: Excellent, knave, how didst thou purchase these?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The staff I stole last night from a sleeping constable;
The rest I borrowed by my acquaintance with
The player's boys; you were best to lose no time sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, so, help boy, 'tis very well, do I not look
Like one that breaks the King's peace with authority?
You know your charge, prepare things handsomely,
My diligent boy, and leave me to my office.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: There wants nothing already; but I fly sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Now fortune prove no slut, and I'll adore thee.
Within. Ser. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A friend would speak with master justice.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am the constable.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My master is not at leisure to hear business.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How? Not at leisure to do the King service;
Take heed what you say sir; I know his worship,
If he knew my business, would no excuse.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You must go to another justice, I'll assure
My master is not well in health.

sp.speaker: Lur
sp.l: I know not,
But if your worshipful be not at leisure
To do himself a benefit, I am gone sir,
An infinite benefit, and the state shall thank him for;
Thank him, and think on him too; I am an officer,
And know my place, but I do love the justice;
I honour any authority above me:
beside, he is my neighbour, and I worship him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You have no books nor ballads Mr. Constable
About you?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What should I do with books does it become
A man of my place to understand such matters?
Pray call your master, if he please to follow me,
I shall discover to him such a plot,
Shall get him everlasting fame, I'll be hanged for't
And he be not knighted instantly, and for reward
Have some of the malefactor's lands I'll bring him too;
But I cannot dally time.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A constable sir, would speak about some business,
He says, will bring you fame, and mighty profit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Please your worship, come down, I'll make you happy;
The notablest piece of villainy I have in hand sir,
And you shall find it out; I ha' made choice
To bring your worship to the first knowledge, and
Thank me, as you find the good on't afterwards.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What is it? Treason?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis little better, I can tell you, I have lodged
A crew of the most rank and desperate villains:
They talk of robberies, and ways they did 'em;
And how they left men bound in their studies.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: With books and ballads?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That sir? that, and murders,
And thousand knaveries more, they're very rich sir,
In money, jewels, chains,, and a hundred more
Devices.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Happy, happy constable, I meet ye
At the back door, get ready knaves.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Not a man I beseech you,
I have privately appointed strength about me,
They cannot start, your men would breed suspicion;
All my desire is you would come alone;
That you might have the hope of the enterprise,
That you might hear 'em first, and then proceed sir,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Keep all my doors fast, 'tis something late.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, so, and please your worship I'll direct you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My master stays, I doubt his lime-twigs catch not,
If they do, all's provided; but I all
This while forget my own state, fair Maria
Is certainly alive, I met her in
Another habit, with her nurse, 'twas she:
There is some trick in't, but when this is over,
I'll find it out, this project for the usurer
May have good effect; however 'twill be sport
To mortify him a little;
He's come without him:
Have you failed sir?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Prospered? my little engineer; away,
He is ith' next room, be not you seen sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The pitfalls ready, never justice
Was caught in such a noose, ere he get out,
He shall run through a scouring purgatory,
Shall purge him to the quick, 'tis night already.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come softly, yet sir softly, are you not weary?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thou'st brought me into a melancholy place,
I see no creature.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: This is, sir, their den
Where they suppose themselves secure, I am saint,
With making haste; but I must be thus troubled,
And therefore never go without a cordial;
Without this I should die;
How it refreshes me
Already? wilt please your worship? I might have had
The manners to ha let you drink before me;
Now am I lusty.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: T'has a good taste.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Taste? how d'ye find the virtue, nay sir spare it not:
My wife has the receipt, dos it not stir
Your worship's body? when you come to examine,
Till make you speak like thunder.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Hoy he.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It works already.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is there never a chair, I was wearier than I thought,
but who shall we have to take 'em, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Let me alone, when I but give the watch word
We will have men enough to surprise an army.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I begin to be sleepy; what, hast a chair?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They do not dream of us, 'tis early rising;
Care, care, and early rising, common wealth's men
Are ever subjects to the nods; sit down sir,
A short nap is not much amiss; so, so, he's fast;
Fast as a fish ith' net, he has winking powder
Shall work upon him to our wish, remove him,
Nay, we may cut him into collops now
And he ne'er feel; have you prepared the vault sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, yes, sir, every thing in's place.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: When we ha' placed him, you an I boy
Must about another project hard by, his potion
Will bind him sure enough till we return,
This villainy weighs mainly, but we'll purge ye.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Now for mine ears, mine ears be constant to me;
They ring a wager, and I must deal justly, ha boys.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Dost hear 'em, hark, these be the ringers?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Are you sure the same?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Or my directions fail;
The coast is clear:
How the bells go? how daintily they tumble?
And methinks they seem to say; fine fools I'll fit you.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Excellent again, good boys — o that was naught.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be you concealed by any moans yet, hark,
They stop, I hope they'll to't again, close sir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A palpable knock.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: 'Twas none.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Be judged by the sexton then,
If I have ears.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: A knock, a knock, a gross one.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Carman, your gallon of wine, you ring most impiously,
Art thou of the worshipful company of the knights oth' West,
and handle a bell with no more dexterity;
You think you are in Thames street
Justling the carts: o a clean hands a jewel.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Good speed to your good exercise.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: You're welcome.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I come sir from a gentleman, and neighbour hard by,
One that loves your music well.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He may have more on't,
Handle a bell, as you were haling timber;
Gross, gross, and base, absurd.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I'll mend it next peal.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: To entreat a knowledge of you, whether it be
By the ear you ring thus cunningly or by the eye;
For to be plain, he has laid ten pounds upon't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But which way has he laid?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That your ear guides you,
And not your eye.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Has won, has won, the ear's our only instrument:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: But how shall we be sure on't.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Put all the lights out, to what end serve our eyes then,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A plain case.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You say true, 'tis a fine cunning thing to ring by th'ear sure:
And can you ring ith' dark so?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: All night long boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis wonderful, let this be certain gentlemen,
And half his wager he allows among ye;
Is't possible you should ring so?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Possible, thou art a child, I'll ring when I am dead drunk;
Out with the lights, no twinkling of a candle,
I know my rope to, as I know my nose,
And can bang it soundly ith' dark, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come let's confirm him straight and win the wager.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Let me hear to strengthen me;
And when you've rung I'll bring the money to you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So so, follow 'em;
They shall have a cool reward, one hath gold of mine,
Good store in's pocket,
But this will be revenged in a short warning.
They are at it lustily; hay, how wantonly
They ring away their clothes, how it delights me;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here, sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Hast Wildbrain's?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: His whole case sir; I felt it out, and by the guards
This should be the coachman's, another suit too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Away boy, quickly now to the usurer,
His hour to wake approaches.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That once finished,
You'll give me leave to play sir: here they come.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am monstrous weary,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Fie, how I sweat? Reach me my cloak to cover me,
I run to oil like a porpoise; 'twas a brave peal.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Let me light my candle first, then I'll wait on you:

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A very brave peal.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Carman, you came in close now.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sure 'tis past midnight.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: No stirring in the streets I hear,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Walk further, was that a pillar? 'tis harder than my nose.
Where's the boy promised us five pound?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Room, I sweat still; come, come, my cloak,
I shall take cold

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Where lies it?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Here, here, and all our clothes.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Ith' corner.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Is thy candle blind too, give me the bottle,
I can drink like a fish now, like an elephant.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Here are the corners, but here are no clothes;
Yes, here is a cuff.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A cuff? give me the candle.
Cuffs won't cover me — I smell a knavery.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Is't come to a cuff? my whole suit turned to a button?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Now am I as cold again as though 'twere Christmas;
Cold with my fear, I'll never ring by the ear more.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: My new clothes vanished?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: My all clothes Toby.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Here's none.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Not one of my dragon's wings left to adorn me
Have I muted all my feathers?

sp.speaker: Wi
sp.l: Cheated by the ear; a plot to put out the candle;
I could be mad; my chain, my rings, the gold, the gold.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: The cold, the cold I cry, and I cry truly,
Not one sleeve, nor a cape of a cloak to warm me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What miserable fools were we?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: We had e'en best, gentlemen,
Every man choose his rope again, and fasten it,
And take a short turn to a better fortune
To be bawds to our miseries, and put our own lights out?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Prithee sexton let's have a fire at thy house,
A good fire, we'll pay thee some way for't, I am stone cold.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Alas I pity you, come quickly gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sure I ha' been in a dream, I had no mistress,
Nor gold, nor clothes, but am a ringing rascal.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Fellows in affliction, let's take hands all,
Now are we fit for tumblers.
sp.stage: Enter Lurcher and others, bringing in Algripe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, so, presently his sleep will leave him.
And wonder seize upon him,
Bid 'em within be ready.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What sound's this?
What horrid din? what dismal place is this?
I never saw before, and now behold it;
But by the half light of a lamp, that burns here:
My spirits shake, tremble through my body;
Help, help,
sp.stage: Enter two furies with black tapers.
sp.l: Mercy, protect me, my soul quakes,
What dreadful apparitions! how I shudder!

sp.speaker: 1, 2 and Fu.
sp.l: Algripe.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What are you?
We are hellhounds hellhounds, that have commission
From the prince of darkness,
To fetch thy black soul to him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Am I not alive still?
Thou art, but we have brought thee instruments
Will quickly rid thy miserable life, stab,
Poison.
Hang thyself, this choice is offered
Thou canst not hope for heaven; thy base soul is
Lost to all hope of mercy.
Quickly, quickly.
The torments cool
And all the fiends expect thee.
Come with us to that pit of endless horror,
Or we will force thee.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: O, o o.
Groans are too late, sooner the ravisher,
Whose soul is hurled into eternal frost,
Stung with the force of twenty thousand winters
To punish the distempers of his blood,
Shall hope to get from thence, than thou avoid
The certainty of meeting hell where he is.
Shall murderers be there for ever dying,
Their souls shot through with adders, torn on engines,
Dying as many deaths for killing one,
Could any imagination number them,
As there be moments in eternity:
And shall that justice spare thee, that hast slain,
Murdered by thy extortion so many?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: O, o.
Do execution quickly, or we'll carry thee alive to hell.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Gently, gentle devils, do not force me
To kill myself, nor do not you do't for me;
O let me live, I'll make amends for all.
Tell us of thy repentance? perjured villain,
Pinch off his flesh, he must be whipped, salted and whipped.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: O misery of miseries!

sp.speaker: Recorders 1 and 2
sp.l: Tear his accursed limbs, to hell with him, ha.
A mischief on that innocent face, away.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Malicious furies hence, choke not the seeds
Of holy penitence.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: This must be an angel,
How at his presence the fiends crawl away!
Here is some light of mercy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be thou wise,
And entertain it, wretched, wretched man;
What poor defence hath all thy wealth been to thee?
What says thy conscience now?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Be my good angel, here I promise thee,
To become honest, and renounce all villainy;
Enjoin me any penance, I'll build churches;
a whole city of hospitals.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Take heed,
There is no dallying, nor are these imposed.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Name any thing within my power, sweet angel;
And if I do not faithfully perform it,
Then whip me every day, burn me each minute,
Whole years together, let me freeze to icicles.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'th number of thy soul oppressions;
Thou hast undone a faithful gentleman,
By taking forfeit of his land.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Young Lurcher,
I do confess.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He lives most miserable,
And in despair may hang or drown himself;
Prevent his ruin, or his blood will be
More sin in thy account: hast thou forgotten
He had a sister?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I do well remember it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Couldst thou for Mammon break thy solemn vow.
Made once to that unhappy maid, that weeps
A thousand tears a day for thy unkindness,
Was not thy faith contracted, and thy heart?
And couldst thou marry another?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: But she's dead,
And I will make true satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What do I instance these, that hast been false
To all the world.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I know it, and will henceforth
Practise repentance, do not frown sweet angel;
I will restore all mortgages, forswear
Abominable usury, live chaste;
For I have been wanton in my shroud, my age;
And if that poor innocent maid, I so abused
Be living, I will marry her, and spend
My days to come religiously.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I was commanded but a messenger
To tell thee this, and rescue thee from those,
Whose malice would have dradged thee quick to hell,
If thou abuse this mercy and repent not,
double damnation will expect thee for it;
But if thy life be virtuous hereafter,
A blessedness shall reward thy good example,
Thy fright hath much distracted thy weak senses,
Drink of this viol, and renew thy spirits,
I ha' done my office, think on't and be happy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, so, he gapes already, now he's fast;
Thou hast acted rarely; but this is not all;
First, help to convey him out o'th vault.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You will dispense with me now, as you promised sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We will make shift without thee, thou'st done well,
By our device this bandog may scape hell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Didst think Maria, this poor outside, and
Dissembling of thy voice could hide thee from
A mother's searching eye, though too much fear,
Lest thou wert not the same, might blind a lover
That thought thee dead too; o my dear Maria,
I hardly kept my joys in from betraying thee:
Welcome again to life, we shall find out
The mystery of thy absence; conceal
Thy person still, for Algripe must not know thee:
And exercise this pretty dialect;
If there be any course in law to free thee,
Thou shalt not be so miserable; be silent
Good nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You shall not need to fear me madam,
I do not love the usuring Jew so well;
Beside, 'twas my trick to disguise her so.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Be not dejected mall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your care may comfort me;
But I despair of happiness.
Hartlove, I dare not see him

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: We'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I shall but grieve to see his passions too,
Since there's no possibility to relieve him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The worlds a labyrinth, where unguided men
walk up and down to find their weariness;
No sooner have we measured with much toil
One crooked path, with hope to gain our freedom,
But it betrays us to a new affliction;
What a strange mockery will man become
Shortly to all the creatures?
O Maria!
If thou beest dead, why does thy shadow fright me I
Sure 'tis because I live; were I but certain
To meet thee in one grave, and that our dust
Might have the privilege to mix in silence,
How quickly should my soul shake off this burden!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thus far my wishes have success, I'll lose
No time: sir, are not you called Mr. Hartlove?
Pardon my rudeness.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What does that concern
Thee boy, 'tis a name cannot advantage thee,
And I am weary on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Had you concealed,
Or I forgotten it sir, so large were my
Directions, that you could not speak this language,
But I should know you by your sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou
Wert well informed, it seems; well, what's your business I

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I come to bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Is Maria
Alive again? that's somewhat, and yet not
Enough to make my expectation rise, to
Past half a blessing, since we cannot meet
To make it up a full one; thou'rt mistaken.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: When you have heard me, you'll think otherwise;
In vain I should report Maria living:
The comfort that I bring you must depend
Upon her death.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou'rt a dissembling boy,
Some one has sent thee to mock me, though my anger
Stoop not to punish thy green years, unripe
For malice; did I know what person sent thee
To tempt my sorrow thus, I should revenge it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed I have no thought so uncharitable,
Nor am I sent to grieve you, let me suffer
More punishment than ever boy deserved,
If you do find me false; I serve a mistress
Would rather die than play with your misfortunes;
Then good sir hear me out.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Who is your mistress?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Before I name her, give me some encouragement,
That you receive her message, she is one
That is full acquainted with your misery,
And can bring such a portion of her sorrow
In every circumstance so like your own,
You'll love and pity her, and wish your griefs
Might marry one another's.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou art wild.
Canst thou bring comfort from so sad a creature?
Her miserable story can at best,
But swell my volume, large enough already.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She was late beloved, as you were, promised faith,
And marriage, and was worthy of a better
Than he, that stole Maria's heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Just as Maria dealt with your affection;
Did he that married her, deal with my mistress,
When careless both of honour and religion;
They cruelly gave away their hearts to strangers.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Part of this truth I know, but prithee boy
Proceed to that thou cam'st for; thou didst promise
Something, thy language cannot hitherto
Encourage me to hope for.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That I come to,
My mistress thus unkindly dealt with all,
You may imagine, wanted no affliction;
And had ere this, wept herself dry as marble,
Had not your fortune come to her relief,
And twin to her own sorrow brought her comfort.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Could the condition of my fate so equal,
Lessen her sufferings?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know not how
Companions in grief sometimes diminish,
And make the pressure easy, by degrees:
She threw her troubles off, remembering yours,
And from her pity of your wrongs, there grew
Affection to your person thus increased,
And with it, confidence, that those whom nature
Had made so even in their weight of sorrow,
Could not but love as equally one another,
Were things but well prepared, this gave her boldness
To employ me thus far.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A strange message boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: If you incline to meet my mistress love,
It may beget your comforts; besides that,
'Tis some revenge, that you above their scorn
And pride, can laugh at them, whose perjury
Hath made you happy, and undone themselves.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Have you done boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Only this little more;
When you but see, and know my mistress well,
You will forgive my tediousness, she's fair,
Fair as Maria was.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'll hear no more,
Go foolish boy, and tell thy fonder mistress
She has no second faith to give away;
And mine; was given to Maria, though her death,
Allow me freedom, see the picture of her,
I would give ten thousand empires for the substance;
Yet for Maria's sake, whose divine figure
That rude frame carries, I will love this counterfeit
Above all the world, and had thy mistress all
The grace and blossom of her sex; now she
Is gone, that was a walking spring of beauty,
I would not look upon her.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, your pardon,
I have but done a message; as becomes
A servant, nor did she on whose commands
I gladly waited, bid me urge her love
to your disquiet, she would chide my diligence
If I should make you angry.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Pretty boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed I fear I have offended you:
Pray if I have, enjoin me any penance for it;
I have performed one duty, and could as willingly
To purge my fault, and show I suffer with you,
Plead your cause to another.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And I'll take thee
At thy word boy, thou hast a moving language,
That pretty innocent, copy of Maria
Is all I love, I know not how to speak,
Win her to think well of me, and I will
Reward thee to thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I undertake
Nothing for gain, but since you have resolved
To love no other, I'll be faithful to you,
And my prophetic thoughts bid me already
Say I shall prosper.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou wert sent to bless me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be happy.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: With your fair leave mistress

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Have you pusiness with her pray you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I have a message from a gentleman,
Please you vouchsafe your ear more private.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You shall have my absence niece.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was the sentleman afeard to declare his matters openly, here was nobody's was not very honest, if her like not her errands the better, was witted to kept her breathes to cool her porridges, can tell her that now for all her private hearings, and tawgings.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You may, if please you, find another language,
And with less pains be understood.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What is her meaning?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come, pray speak your own English.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Have boys lost her jots and memories? pless us all.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I must be plain then, come, I know you are
Maria, this thin veil cannot obscure you:
I'll tell the world you live, I have not lost ye,
Since first with grief and shame to be surprised,
A violent trance took away show of life;
I could discover by what accident
You were conveyed away at midnight, in
Your coffin, could declare the place, and minute,
When you revived, and what you have done since as perfectly —

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Alas, I am betrayed to new misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are not for my knowledge, I'll be dumb
For ever, rather than be such a traitor;
Indeed I pity you, and bring no thoughts,
But full of peace, call home your modest blood,
Pale hath too long usurped upon your face;
Think upon love again, and the possession
Of full blown joys, now ready to salute you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: These words undo me more than my own griefs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I see how fear would play the tyrant with you,
But I'll remove suspicion; have you in
Your heart an entertainment for his love,
To whom your virgin faith made the first promise?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If thou meanest Hartlove, thou dost wound me still,
I have no life without his memory,
Nor with it any hope to keep it long,
Thou seest I walk in darkness like a thief,
That fears to see the world in his own shape,
My very shadow frights me, 'tis a death
To live thus, and not look day in the face,
Away, I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You shall hereafter know, and thank me lady,
I'll bring you a discharge at my next visit,
Of all your fears, be content fair Maria,
'Tis worth your wonder

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be wise and silent,
Dress yourself, you shall be what you wish.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Do this, and be
My better angel.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: All your cares on me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I must applaud thy diligence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: It had been nothing
To ha' left him in the porch; I called his servants,
With wonders they acknowledged him, I pretended
It was some spice sure of the falling sickness,
And that was charity to bring him home;
They rubbed and chafed him, plied him with strong water,
Still he was senseless, clamours could not wake him;
I wished 'em then get him to bed, they did so,
And almost smothered him with rugs and pillows;
And cause they should have no cause to suspect me,
I watched them till he waked.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: When his time came to yawn, and stretch himself,
I bid 'em not be hasty to discover
How he was brought home, his eyes fully open,
With trembling he began to call his servants,
And told 'em he had seen strange visions,
That should convert him from his heathen courses;
They wondered, and were silent, there he preached
How sweet the air of a contented conscience
Smelled in his nose now, asked 'em all forgiveness
For their hard pasture since they lived with him;
Bid 'em believe, and fetch out the cold sirloin:
Pierce the strong beer and let the neighbour's joy in't:
The concealed muskadine should now lie open
To every mouth; that he would give toth' poor,
And mend their wages; that his doors should be
Open to every miserable suitor.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What said his servants then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They durst not speak,
But blessed themselves, and the strange means that had
Made him a christian in this overjoy,
I took my leave, and bade 'em say their prayers,
and humour him, lest he turned Jew again.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Enough, enough. Who's this?
'Tis one of my ringers; stand close, my lady's coachman.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat;
Would I were at rack and manger among my horses;
We have divided the sexton's
Household stuff amongst us, one has the rug, and he's
Turned Irish, another has a blanket, and he must beg in't,
The sheets serve another for a frock, and with the bed-cord,
He may pass for a porter, nothing but the mat would fall
To my share, which with the help of a tune and a hassock
Out oth' church may disguise me till I get home;
A pox a bell-ringing by the ear, if any man take me
At it again, let him pull mine to the pillory, I could wish
I had lost mine ears, so I had my clothes again;
The weather won't allow this fashion,
I do look for an ague besides.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How the rascal shakes?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Here are company:
Buy a mat for a bed, but a mat,
A hassock for your feet, or a piss clean and sweet;
Buy a mat for a bed, by a ma:
Ringing, I renounce thee, I'll never come to church more.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You with a mat?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am called.
If any one should offer to buy my mat, what a case were I in?
O that I were in my oat tub with a horse-loaf,
Something to hearten me:
I dare not hear 'em;
Buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He's deaf.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am glad I am: buy a mat for a bed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How the rascal sweats? What a pickle he's in?
Every street he goes through will be a new torment,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: If ever I meet at midnight more a jangling:
I am cold, and yet I drop; buy a mat for a bed buy a mat.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He has punishment enough.
Who's this, my tother youth? he is turned bear.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am half afraid of myself: this poor shift
I got oth' sexton to convey me handsomely
To some harbour, the wench will hardly know me;
They'll take me for some watchman oth' parish;
I ha' never a penny left me, that's one comfort;
And ringing has begotten a monstrous stomach,
And that's another mischief, I were best go home,
For every thing will scorn me in this habit.
Besides, I am so full of these young bell-ringers;
If I get in adoors, not the power oth' country,
Nor all my aunt's curses shall disembogue me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Bid her come hither presently, — hum, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am betrayed to one that will eternally laugh at me,
Three of these rogues will jeer a horse to death.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Wildbrain sure, and yet methinks
His fashion's strangely altered; sirrah watchman,
You rugamuffin, turn you lousy bear's skin:
You with the bedrid bill.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Has found me out;
There's no avoiding him, I had rather now
Be arraigned at Newgate for a robbery
Than answer to his articles: your will sir,
I am in haste.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay then I will make bold wi'ye;
A watchman and ashamed to show his countenance,
His face of authority; I have seen that physiognomy;
Were you never in prison for pilfering?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How the rogue worries me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why may not this
Be the villain robbed my house last night,
And walks disguised in this malignant rug,
Armed with a ton of iron, I will have you
Before a magistrate.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What art thou? speak.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am the wand'ring Jew, and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: By your leave rabbi, I will show you then
A synagogue, yclept Bridewell, where you
Under correction may rest yourself;
You have brought a bill to guard you, there be dog whips
to firk such rugged curs, whips without bells
Indeed.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Bells.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How he sweets?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I must be known, as good at first; now, jeer on,
But do not anger me too impudently,
The rabbi will be moved then.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How? Jacks Wildbrains
What time oth' moon man, ha? what strange bells
Hast in thy brains.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No more bells,
No more bells, they ring backwards.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Why, where's the wench, the blessing that befell thee?
The unexpected happiness? where's that Jack?
Where are thy golden days?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: It was his trick as sure as I am lousy,
But how to be revenged —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Jack,
Marry a watchman's widow in thy young days,
With a revenue of old iron, and a rug,
Is this the paragon, the dainty piece,
The delicate divine rogue?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: 'Tis enough I am undone,
Marked for a misery, and so leave prating;
Give me my bill,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You need not ask your tailors,
Unless you had better linings; it may be
To avoid suspicion you are going thus
Disguised to your fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Mock no further,
Or as I live I'll lay my bill o'thy pate,
I'll take a watchman's fury into my fingers,
To ha' no judgement to distinguish persons
And knock thee down.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Come, I ha' done, and now
Will speak some comfort to thee, I will lead thee
Now to my mistress hither to concealed;
She shall take pity on thee too, she loves
A handsome man; thy misery invites me
To do thee good, I'll not be jealous Jack;
Her beauty shall commend itself; but do not
When I have brought you into grace supplant me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Art thou in earnest, by this cold iron —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: No oaths, I am not costive; here she comes:
Sweet heart, I have brought a gentleman,
a friend of mine to be acquainted with you,
He's other than he seems; why d'ye stare thus?

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: O sir, forgive me, I have done you wrong.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What's the matter? didst ever see her of re Jack?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Prithee do what thou wilt wi'me, if thou hast
A mind, hang me up quickly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Never despair, I'll give thee my share rather,
Take her, I hope she loves thee at first sight,
She has petticoats will patch thee up a suit;
I resign all, only I'll keep these trifles,
I took some pains for 'em, I take it Jack;
What think you pink of beauty, come let me
Counsel you both to marry, she has a trade,
If you have audacity to hook in gamesters:
Let's ha' a wedding, you will be wondrous rich;
For she is impudent, and thou art miserable;
'Twill be a rare match.

sp.speaker: Mi
sp.l: As you are a man forgive me, I'll redeem all.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You won't to these gear of marriage then?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, I thank you Tom, I can watch for
A groat a night, and be every gentleman's fellow.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Rise, and be good, keep home and tend your business.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou hast don't to purpose, give me thy hand Tom;
Shall we be friends? thou seest what state I am in,
I'll undertake this penance to my aunt,
Just as I am, and openly I'll go;
Where, if I be received again for currant,
And fortune smile once more —

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I me satisfied, so farewell honest lousy Jack.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I cannot help it, some men meet with strange destinies.
If things go right thou mayst be hanged, and I
May live to see't, and purchase thy apparel:
So farewell Tom, commend me to thy polecat.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Now that I have my counsel ready, and my cause ripe;
The judges all informed of the abuses;
Now that he should be gone.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: No man knows whether,
and yet they talk he went forth with a constable
That told him of strange business, that would bring him
Money and lands, and heaven knows what; but they
Have searched, and can not find out such an officer:
And as a secret, madam, they told your man
Nicholas, whom you sent thither as a spy,
They had a shrewd suspicion 'twas the devil
I'th likeness of a constable, that has tempted him
By this time to strange things; there have been men
As rich as he, have met convenient rivers,
And so forth; many trees have born strange fruits:
D'ye think he has not hanged himself?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: If he be hanged, who has his goods?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They are forfeited, they say.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He has hanged himself for certain then,
Only to cozen me of my girl's portion.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Or did not the constable carry him to some prison?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They thought on that too, and searched everywhere .

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He may be close for treason, perhaps executed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, they did look among the quarters too,
And mustered all the bridge-house for his nightcap.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Madam, here is the gentleman again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He that loved my young mistress.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Alas, 'tis heartlove, 'twill but feed his melancholy,
To let him see Maria, since we dare not
Yet tell the world she lives; and certainly,
Did not the violence of his passion blind him,
He would see passed her borrowed tongue and habit.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Please you entertain him a while madam,
I'll cast about for some thing with your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Do what thou wot, pray Mr. Hartlove enter.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam, I come to ask your gentle pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pardon, for what? you never offended me,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, if you be the mother of Maria.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I was her mother, but that word is cancelled,
and buried with her in that very minute
Her soul fled from her, we lost both our names
Of mother and of daughter.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Alas, madam,
If your relation did consist but in
Those naked terms, I had a title nearer,
Since love unites more than the tie of blood;
No matter for the empty voice of mother;
Your nature still is left, which in her absence
Must love Maria, and not see her ashes
And memory polluted.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You amaze me, by whom?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By me, I am the vile profaner.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why do you speak thus indiscreetly sir?
You ever honoured her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I did alive,
But since she died, I ha' been a villain to her.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I do beseech you say not so; all this
Is but to make me know, how much I sinned
In forcing her to marry.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Do not mock me,
I charge you by the virgin you have wept for;
For I have done an impious act against her,
A deed able to fright her from her sleep,
And through her marble, oft to be revenged;
A wickedness, that if I should be silent,
You as a witness must accuse me for't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Was I a witness?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, you knew I loved
Maria once; or grant, you did but think so,
By what I ha' professed, or she has told you,
Was't not a fault unpardonable in me,
When I should drop my tears upon her grave.
Yes, and propose sufficient.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That I forgetful of my fame and vows
To fair Maria, ere the worm could pierce
Her tender shroud, had changed her for another;
Did you not blush to see me turn a rebel?
So soon to court a shadow, a strange thing,
Without a name? Did you not curse my levity,
Or think upon her death with the less sorrow
That she had scaped a punishment more killing,
o how I shame to think on't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Sir in my
Opinion, 'twas an argument of love
To your Maria, for whose sake you could
Affect one that but carried her small likeness.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No more, you are too charitable, but
I know my guilt, and will from henceforth never
Change words with that strange maid, whose innocent face
Like your Maria's won so late upon me,
My passions are corrected, and I can
Look on her now, and woman kind, without
Love in a thought; 'tis thus, I came to tell you.
If after this acknowledgement, you'll be
So kind to show me in what silent grave
You have disposed your daughter, I will ask
Forgiveness of all her dust, and never leave,
Till with the loud confession of my shame
I wake her ghost, and that pronounce my pardon:
Will you deny this favour? then farewell,
I'll never see you more: ha!
sp.stage: Enter nurse, Maria in her own apparel, after some show of wonder he goes towards her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Be not deluded sir, upon my life
This is the soul whom you but thought Maria
In my daughter's habit; what did you mean nurse?
I knew she would but cozen you, is she not like now?
One dew unto another is not nearer.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She thinks she is a gentlewoman;
And that imagination has so taken her,
She scorns to speak, how handsomely she carries it,
As if she were a well bread thing, her body?
And I warrant you, what looks?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Pray be not foolish.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I disturb nobody , speak but half a word
And I am satisfied, but what needs that?
I'll swear 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But do not, I beseech you,
For trust me sir, you know not what I know.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Peace then,
and let me pray, she holds up her hands with me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: This will betray all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Love ever honoured,
And ever young, thou sovereign of all hearts,
Of all our sorrows, the sweet ease,
Does she still cozen me?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You will see anon,
'Twas her desire, expect the issue madam.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My souls so big, I cannot pray; 'tis she,
I will go nearer.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Here's Mr. Algripe and other strangers madam.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here good lady,
Upon my knees I ask thy worship's pardon;
Here's the whole sum I had with thy fair daughter;
Would she were living, I might have her peace too,
And yield her up again to her old liberty:
I had a wife before, and could not marry;
My penance shall be on that man that honoured her
To confer some land.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: This is incredible.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis truth.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Do you know me sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ha, the gentleman I deceived.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My name is Lurcher.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Shalt have thy mortgage.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I ha that already, no matter for the deed
If you release it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'll do't before thy witness;
But where's thy sister? if she live I am happy, though
I conceal our contract, which was
Stolen from me with the evidence of this land.
sp.stage: The boy goes to Maria and gives her a paper; she wonders, and smiles upon Hartlove, he amazed approaches her: afterwards she shows it her mother, and then gives it to Hartlove.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Your daughter smiles.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I hope she lives, but where, I cannot tell sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Even here, and please you sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis she;
To work thy fair way, I preserved you brother,
That would have lost me willingly, and served ye
Thus like a boy; I served you faithfully,
And cast your plots but to preserve your credit;
Your foul ones I diverted to fair uses;
so far as you would hearken to my counsel;
That all the world may know how much you owe me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Welcome entirely, welcome my dear Alathe,
And when I lose the again, blessing forsake me:
Nay, let me kiss thee in these clothes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And I too,
And bless the time I had so wise a sister, were't thou the little thief?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I stole the contract, I must confess,
And kept it to myself, it most concern me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Contracted? this destroys his after marriage.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Dare you give this hand
To this young gentleman, my heart goes with it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Maria alive I how my hearts exalted, 'tis my duty;
Take her Frank Hartlove, take her; and all joys
With her; besides some land to advance her jointure.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What I have is your own, and blessings crown ye.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give me room,
And fresh air to consider, gentlemen,
My hopes are too high.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Be more temperate,
Or I'll be Welsh again.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A day of wonder.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Lady, your love, I ha' kept my word; there was
A time, when my much sufferings made me hate you,
And to that end I did my best to cross you:
And fearing you were dead I stole your coffin,
That you might never more usurp my office:
Many more knacks I did, which at the weddings
Shall be told of as harmless tales.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hallow your throats a pieces, I am at home;
If you can roar me out again —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What thing is this?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A continent of fleas: room for the pageant;
Make room afore there; your kinsman madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My kinsman? let me wonder!

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do, an I'll wonder too, to see this company
At peace one with another; 'tis not worth
your admiration, I was never dead yet;
You're merry aunt, I see, and all your company:
If ye be not, I'll fool up, and provoke ye;
I will do any thing to get your love again:
I'll forswear midnight taverns and temptations;
Give good example to your grooms, the maids
Shall go to bed and take their rest this year;
None shall appear with blisters in their bellies.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And when you will fool again, you may go ring.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Madam, have mercy.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Your submission sir,
I gladly take, we will
Inquire the reason of this habit afterwards;
Now you are soundly shamed, well wi' restore you:
Where's Toby?
Where's the coachman?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He's a-bed , madam,
And has an ague, he says.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I'll be his physician.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: We must a foot then.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ere the priest ha' done
Toby shall wait upon you with his coach,
And make your Flanders mares dance back again wi'ye,
I warrant you madam you are mortified,
Your suit shall be granted too.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Make, make room afore there.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Home forward with glad hearts, home child.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I wait you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: On joyfully, the cure of all our grief,
Is owing to this pretty little these.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
